values: A crisis struck in Action Figure Land today when I brought home a package of green Peeps. The Librarian very understandably decided they were a threat, but most of the rest of the toys really liked them. Peeps are exotic, both soft and grainy -- textures most action figures don't get to experience very often. Unfortunately, the Librarian managed to ally himself with the My Little Pony, and with size, hooves, and opposable thumbs on their side, along with the fact that the weapons they faced were plastic, they rounded up all the peeps and most of the toys. They chained them together with yarn and were all set to drive the snakes Peeps from Ireland Action Figure Land. It was looking grim for the Peeps, Tiny Han, Tiny Luke, Tiny R2, Donkey, Baby Goat, and Penguin. But! Captain Jack, Rose, Tiny Leia, One-Armed Willow and Oz had a plan. Luckily they were experts at hiding in foliage, so they remained completely unseen in a Christmas cactus while the slave train got on its way. Then they stood around and waited for K-9 to enact the whole plan, which involved pulling the yarn back and forth very quickly so that it worked up static electricity, sparked, and jumped right off of the captives. (Science is special in Action Figure Land.) With everyone distracted, Jack and Rose tackled the Pony, Oz played a song on his guitar to draw away the Peeps (very pied piper), and Willow reasoned with the Librarian. Tiny Leia made sure the other captives were okay. In the end, the Librarian agreed to a less drastic solution. Again, K-9 was key. Most people don't know that when wool/synthetic blend yarn is electrified twice in a row, the polarity of its neutron flow reverses and it can be used to transport small synthetic objects through time and space. All they had to do was put the Peeps inside a circle of yarn, and ZAP, they were sent back to their home planet, Peeprica. Hooray! (Clicking some photos leads to a larger version with better detail) Librarian leading the train of captives Peeps & penguin in bondage. You can see where one Peep has had its nose dented by a kick from the Pony. This is where the Jack, Rose, Tiny Leia, Willow and Oz hid. They're so well hidden, you probably can't see them, so you'll just have to take my word for it. K-9 bringing up the rear Unexpected Furry Menace! All's well that transports well

After their disappointing quest through the wilderness for the wrong Blue Box, the Plastic Captain, Plastic Rose, and tiny K-9 took their silver Honda landcruiser a long distance to a new place. The Captain called it a "base of ops" and Rose called it a "bloody huge flat."



In their headquarters on a muslin covered table, which for some reason the Captain insisted on called "the Hub," the trio discovered some heavy, smooth, round objects of several different colors. They inspected one.

Rose bent her head with some difficulty and rubbed her cheek against the object. "It feels like those rocks I fell on," she observed. "But it's round," the Captain countered. None of them had ever seen a round stone. In their experience, stones were angular and pokey. CORRECTION, MASTER. IT IS OVOID, said K-9. Jack was a little annoyed, feeling that "round" was close enough, but he kept silent. EGGS ARE OVOID, K-9 added. "An egg?" Rose said thoughtfully. "That's... a bit creepy. Look how many there are. What if they hatched?" "K-9, can you analyze them?" the Captain asked. NEGATIVE, CAPTAIN, MY CIRCUITS ARE PLASTIC. "Oh, well, watch them for any signs of... loss of integrity, will you? Just in case they are eggs, we don't want the Hub turning into a nursery. Or battleground," he added, thinking of all the things an egg could contain. K-9 watched.

The Captain and Rose decided to climb down and have a look around. Rose had spotted some interesting-looking boxes on the floor sporting life-sized advertisements of a variety of men. For some reason she was drawn to them. They shimmied down the leg of the table, but quickly found that the surface on the lower level was soft and very hard to stand in.

However, as often happens in life, they found that hanging onto one another for support helped their balance greatly. They turned their attention to the first box.

It showed three men, one of whom frightened Rose and made the Captain laugh out loud. The other two were strange-looking but gave Rose no other clues. She did notice the writing, though.

"Why does it say 'Doctor'?" She wondered. "Doctor who? Not our Doctor, whoever he is?" "I doubt it," the Captain agreed, "but you're right, it's quite a coincidence to find the name here." They continued to the next box.

Suddenly the Captain's entire body felt gooey with the warmth of shock. The picture on this box showed Rose, but it was the man pictured next to her that made his joints thicken. There was something about that man. "Jack!" Rose stopped usinghis title in moments of stress. "Look! It's... I'm sure that's the box from my dreams! Police Box! It's blue!" But it was just a photograph, after all, and they didn't know what to do with the information yet, so they continued to the third box, gripping one anothers' arms stiffly but with feeling.

This poster showed Rose again, but with another man. The new man was rather cheeky-looking. Jack didn't like him, and felt strangely protective of the Rose in this third picture. Plastic Rose was adding things up. "Jack," she said quietly, "all three of these boxes say 'Doctor. 'They're all different men, but two of them show me, and two have the Blue Box. What's going on?" She finished almost plaintively. "I don't like it." Jack agreed. "It's like we've almost found what we're looking for, but at the same time it's not even close. I've got a bad feeling, too. What's in these boxes?" They moved to investigate more closely, but the boxes were quite secure, and the two ended up losing their balance again.

By this time, K-9, having judged the Mystery Eggs safe for the moment, had found a way down and joined them. The moment he saw the three boxes, he popped a panel.

THESE ARE ALL DOCTORS, he said flatly but somehow betraying surprise at the same time. "We figured out that much, you brilliant tin box," Jack said, helping Rose up off the carpet. "But they're not *our* Doctor, are they?" THEY ARE NOT REAL, K-9 confirmed. "So we keep searching," Jack said, nodding as much as his neck joint would allow. "I just wish I knew what these boxes were for." The three returned, with considerable difficulty to the Hub, where Jack and Rose tried to relieve the stress of the outing with their favorite activity, Doing the Splits While Holding Hands. K-9 watched protectively.

High above, other action figures were watching the drama unfold. In particular, one called Giles and another called Willow, veterans of many plasticene existential crises, smiled to themselves and shook their heads sadly. The revelations for these new Plastic people were going to get more painful before they started making sense.  

Next time: Enter the Librarian

(Previously in the adventures...) After smuggling themselves out of the hotel room in some luggage, then stowing away on several airplanes which the Captain insisted he could have flown if they weren't trying to be so secretive, the Captain and Rose found themselves in an area of rural America. It seemed as good a place as any to begin searching for the Doctor, so they procured seats in a silver Honda landship and rode around with their painted eyes peeled, so to speak. On their first day out, Rose spotted, far in the distance, Something Blue. She revealed to the Captain that she had been having dreams about a particular shade of blue, and it seemed like paint on wood. They decided to follow the clue. It took them to the road up a mountain, which also happened to be blue. The first time they were able to disembark, Rose and the Captain quickly became separated. Jack searched the mountainside frantically. "ROSE!" he shouted as loud as he could from the top of a cliff, disturbing a beetle nearby. But Rose could not hear him. She was lying senseless on a cliff ledge far below. Tiny plastic boots do not promote agility, as it turns out. Fortunately, K-9 had joined the search. 'I HAVE FOUND ROSE, MASTER,' he announced, and his projection was surprisingly good across the canyon that separated him from the Captain. The Captain eventually found his way around and climbed down to help Rose. < "I am dashing and heroic! Look at my uniform!" he reassured her after waking her gently. "I am strong and manly, trust me!"  They climbed up together. The climb was exhausting. Later, when the Honda landcruiser had reached the top of the mountain, K-9 used his navigation technology to lead them across a ridge. Fortunately, there was already a trail carved in the direction they needed to go. < Still, it was steep and fairly treacherous for people six inches high with only eight points of articulation. In fact, during one climb, the Captain found himself hanging with no more footholds. < "I thought you were dashing and strong and manly," Rose called back down to him. "Can't you get yourself up?" The Captain uttered exclamations that were neither dashing nor heroic.< "Okay, grab my hands," Rose offered, lying on her stomach and risking scratching her paint on the rock to help him. "Wait, just one hand, otherwise you'll fall."< Either Rose was surprisingly strong or the Captain was made of surprisingly light, tough material, because Rose had no trouble pulling him up. He was very tired from his ordeal and simply had to rest with his head in her lap for some time. Meanwhile, K-9 kept watch, yielding to neither Virginia creeper nor poison ivy. Finally, the group made it to the end of the trail, where they could survey the entire valley for Rose's blue object. K-9, using a built-in electrotelescope, spotted a blue, boxlike thing miles below and noted the coordinates. He was about to turn away when he decided to zoom in a little closer. 'MISTRESS, THE BOX READS: Porta-John.  I DO NOT BELIEVE THIS IS THE OBJECT WE SEEK.' Rose, after searching her hopeful plastic heart, asking if the sign on the John object said anything about a Smith, and being told 'NEGATIVE,' was forced to agree. The group was rather dejected. The Captain, however, had noticed dozens of carvings in the wood of the landing they were standing on. Most of the carvings were of the [boy] + [girl] = [heart] variety, leading him to believe this must be the fabled Lovers Leap. To cheer Rose up and honor the place, Captain Jack insisted they practice their dancing some more. When they had reached lower altitude again, the Captain snuck away to stand on the edge of something very high. Rose spotted him and climbed up after him, mentally preparing arguments to convince him not to jump. In her worry, she called him "Jack" for the first time. However, it turned out he had picked the spot merely for its suitability for brooding. Once the brooding was accomplished, Rose joined the Captain and they stood together in what they thought was probably a very heroic stance. It made them feel heroic, anyway, and then they were off to continue their mission, sure that someday, they would find the Doctor.

(Prologue) Unfortunately, soon after meeting and discovering their purpose, AFs Captain Jack and Rose investigated and discovered further that they were locked in a giant hotel room. They decided to use their time of incarceration to explore their bodies. "Look, Captain, I can do the splits!" Rose said with delight, demonstrating. She promptly fell forward onto her face. "But I guess I need to work on balance." The Captain tried and found that he, too, could do the splits; but his difficulty was falling backwards. The two were forced to grasp hands to stay upright while they practiced balancing, presumably for a future time when they would be "served" by a gymastic dance team. Threatdown: BEARS The two were so wrapped up in each other practicing the splits they don't notice the smiling plush giant behind them. K-9 noticed, however, and would have sounded the alert but for the curious scarf the bear wore. It aroused in K-9 electronic impulses that in an organic life form would have been an unplaceable sense of nostalgia. K-9 settled for making friends with the bear, whose name was Beatrice. Later, Beatrice returned, evidently after taking a walk in a tropical paradise (or possibly a hothouse). Rather than questioning the bear about how she escaped from the hotel room, Rose (who wasn't yet well-practiced in the ways of action/adventure) procured a flower from her. Rose decided to give Captain Jack her flower. The Captain accepted. Good dog. Later, K-9 was unable to locate the two action figures, but he remained to belatedly guard Rose's flower. When the Captain and Rose showed up again, they noticed music coming from the adjoining hotel room and took the opportunity to try dancing, presumably in preparation for a time when they would be "served" by a nasty team of ballroom dancers.<

On August 11, 2007, two small plastic people awoke surrounded by colorful paper board and several large, transparent plastic shields. They tried to introduce themselves to one another but found they did not know their own names--or much of anything. "Like, what is this place? How did we get here?" the female said, trying to stand and finding herself quite stiff. The ground was too soft to support her. "And what do I look like?" The female looked serious. "You look fantastic," the male said appreciatively, raising a painted eyebrow, and then they caught one another's eyes and stared for a moment, as if a memory had been triggered. "Say that again," said the girl. "What? You look great. Now how about me?" The man looked almost as serious, but with poutier lips. "No, that isn't what you said. You said FANTASTIC." They both shivered in their plastic clothes. But the moment passed without revelation. The man rolled over to attempt standing and discovered it was easier if he used one of the colorful boards. Once he was standing, he had a better view of the decorations. "Hey, would ya look at that. It's you! And I think your name is K-9. Do you have 'PULL BACK & GO' Motion?" The girl had no idea if she could pull back & go, as she was having difficulty managing to stand at all. She finally made her way across the soft surface to the board where the man was standing, then wrinkled her plastic nose. "Is that what I look like? My roots are showing." The man looked at her critically. "Yup. That's you. But don't worry about the hair. You're a real doll." This made the girl smile. "Are you sure about the name? What's that... thing behind me, with the antennae? Is that Rose?" "A mechanical fly or something? I don't know. More importantly, is there a picture of me around here?" They moved two of the transparent screens with some difficulty, but didn't have to search long before they found a board with a picture of the man. "Jack Harkness!" the man said triumphantly. "Now that's a good solid name. And I'm a captain!" K-9 attempted to salute him good-naturedly but found her arms didn't bend quite that way. She began reading the boards in more detail. "What's this about a CHOKING HAZARD, Captain?" she wondered aloud. "Mmm, probably means we have to be careful when we eat," he said wisely. "What I'm more concerned about is this 'sonic blaster accessory' I'm supposed to have. Have you seen it?" K-9 had been about to ask about the large, attractive label "DOCTOR WHO" below the Captain's name, but she let that go and helped the Captain search for his gun. While they were attempting to lift a piece of board together, suddenly a loud voice behind them made K-9 yelp and the Captain drop the board. 'HELLO MASTERS. I HAVE FOUND THE SONIC BLASTER YOU SEEK.' They turned around, K-9 panting in her partially-unbuttoned shirt, and discovered the metal fly from the picture. Now it looked more like... they weren't sure until K-9 saw the collar around its neck. "Hello, you cute thing, are you a doggy?" she said to it. With a mechanical whir, the creature backed up an inch. 'THE DIMINUTIVE LABEL YOU CHOOSE IS CORRECT, MISTRESS. I AM A DOG.' Then it returned to its original point. 'I HAVE FOUND THE BLASTER. COME.' It swung around, spun its wheels for a few seconds in a fold of the very soft ground, gained traction, and took off. The Captain and K-9 followed it back to one of the transparent screens, where the gun was secured tightly with a large piece of wire. The Captain tried to remove it but found his fingers were not dexterous enough for the job. "K-9, you want to have a go?" The girl and the mechanical dog moved forward at the same time. The dog's head rotated to look at the girl. 'I AM K-9, MISTRESS.' If it had been anyone else, its tone would have said, "I'm surrounded by idiots." The girl laughed. "Kay-nine," she sounded out. "Right. Well that's much better, I must be Rose!" She shook hands with the Captain as if introducing herself, then gave the dog a pat on the head. "It's nice to meet you, K-9." The real K-9 was able to use a cutting tool to make short work of the wire securing the blaster. The Captain held the gun in his hand, looking pleased. But K-9 was not ready to relax. He swung around to face both of his new friends. 'NOW WE MUST FIND THE DOCTOR.' The Captain and Rose looked at each other with amazement. "The Doctor!" they said simultaneously, for all at once the memories had come flooding back.

Regular Xander's report on the latest episode of SG-1, "Babylon." Military Xander and Magic Box Anya watched with him this week. R Xander: Well, it was kind of predictable and boring again unless you like shirtless men-- MB Anya: It was the best episode yet. R Xander: --or you like Jaffa culture. Military Xander: It was pretty interesting. And you're not lying about the shirtless men. Mitchell, um... MB Anya: How about that Jaffa in the Army basement hospital thingy place? He had even prettier boobs than Cordy. Willow: Xander, can't you at least get her to call them 'pectoral muscles'? Giles: Yes yes, well, this is all... appalling, and I'd like to hear more about Jaffa culture later, but let's get to the point. Was there mention of this, ah, 'Origin' religion? R Xander: That's what I was trying to say if my pervy girlfriend would shut up-- MB Anya: You're just sulking because Vala isn't on anymore. R Xander: (ignoring her) --that the Priors have been wiping out more planets of people who refuse to worship the Ori. But these super-secret special Jaffa on this one planet, they escaped the Goa'uld and they've been isolated for hundreds of years worshipping, get this, the Ancients. Giles: Are these Goa'uld important? R Xander: Uh... I guess you just need to know they made slaves out of the Jaffa and forced everybody to worship them as gods. Oz: And they held power by... R Xander: Being mean bastards. Giles: Power. R Xander: Yeah, basically. Stolen technology, lies. Nothing supernatural about them. So anyway, these special Jaffa rejected the Goa'uld as false gods and decided the Ancients were the real deal. But after all this time their leader, the one Mitchell met, starts getting antsy because they pray to the Ancients but the Ancients never reveal themselves. And of course then a Prior shows up in the flesh, does all his hocus pocus with the healing and the crops, and the Jaffa leader really likes all this. He knows the Ori aren't Ancients, but they're *right there*. And they're powerful. They're some kind of god. Oz: But not the right kind of god. R Xander: Right, that's what Mitchell said. He said they're not worthy because of how they *use* their power, force people to worship them by doing bad stuff. He says people shouldn't suffer for their faith. Giles: So this fellow defines "god" as one who has a certain amount of a certain kind of power, but believes that only benevolent gods should be worshipped. Oz: Or at least that malevolent ones shouldn't be. R Xander: Mitchell wanted those guys to go back to worshipping the Ancients even though the Ancients don't talk back. Giles: Things unseen. Fascinating. These Jaffa fellows reject one god as a mortal trickster, embrace another on faith, only to abandon that one for a god who is less distant but more cruel. R Xander: Yup. Oz: The religion vacuum. It gets filled one way or another. Willow: But some people don't believe in any gods, right? Giles: Individuals, yes. But I believe Oz is right: whole societies, cultures with a habit of religion, I doubt they can survive without worshipping *something*, even if it's not a god per se. Willow: And something you can see is better than something you can't see, even if it's a mean something? Giles: Well, I suppose that's the question. Xander, you mentioned that your "Stargate" program said something about faith? R Xander: Oh, right. Yup. Mitchell went on about it to the Jaffa leader guy. He said Earth people never needed proof of their gods' existence in order to believe in them. Giles: Ah. AF Willow, AF Cordelia, and the Anyas have had a tough couple of weeks, what with their research assignments covering the internet, non-sci fi television, and radio. Willow is worried about all the action figures in New Orleans who may be covered with toxic muck. She's convinced (rightly so, though I didn't say it) that nobody's going to take care of the stranded action figures, and she wanted to start doing science experiments with polluted water to see how it reacts with plastic and paint, but Giles and Military Xander stepped in. It was a little tense for awhile, though.

It's busy at Casa Rusty these days. I come home and the TiVo remote has been moved, books from the metal shelf are out of place, new bookmarks have appeared on my Foxfire browser. The Action Figures are beelike. They meet almost every night to share what they've found. Military Xander and Faith work together with a matchbox they found and light the candle in the blue holder, and they sit or lie around it, being careful not to get within meltin-distance. I think Oz has sat down and watched all the Battlestar Galactica episodes I have on the TiVo (all of Season 2 so far), and the other night he and Military Xander started to inform the others about the most recent episode. Even I hadn't seen it yet, so I took some risk eavesdropping on their conversation. AF Oz: I think what we need to concentrate on are the Colonists' mythology and the Cylons' religion. Fiesta Giles: (intrigued) Why do you call one a mythology and the other a religion? Is that how it's presented? M Xander: The first one just... sounds older? Some of them really believe it though. And there's some sort of magicky stuff like when Willow starts burning sage... Giles wanted to know what Xander meant by "older" and Oz started to describe the ancient stories and writings versus the Cylons' apparent concept of a single, living God. They ended up watching it again so Giles could see for himself (Willow joined them), and he got very excited by the names he was hearing, and the next day I noticed my copy of Edith Hamilton's Mythology was taken down and a bunch of Battlestar Galactica bookmarks on my computer. Tonight they talked it out briefly in council. Giles: Kobol was the home of the gods? Oz: Lords of Kobol. Zeus, Apollo, Hera, Athena, Artemis, and Aphrodite, maybe more. Military Xander: And humans lived there. Oz: Worshipping the gods, everything was ducky. M Xander: There was even a pretty opera house! Giles: But then the humans abandoned it. AF Willow: (it must have been she who did the internet portion of the research for Oz) After getting pretty depraved, well, according to the Cylons anyway. There was some kind of attack or war or something, too. Two thousand years ago. Giles: Twelve colonies. Willow: Thirteen. They went out and found new planets, and they lost Kobol, and they also lost Earth for some reason, the thirteenth colony. But they had an oracle named Pythia, or they had her scrolls from 1600 years before, anyway. So they know things like "All of this has happened before, and all of this will happen again"-- Oz: History is cyclical. Willow: --and the fact that there's a place on Kobol that will show the way to Earth if you take the right sacred object in with you. Buffy: The arrow of Apollo. AF Faith: ::snort:: Apollo can take his own arrow. Giles: But the planet is in ruins now. M Xander: After the colonials left, Athena was so upset she jumped off a cliff. Zeus or one of them saw it and made the tomb for her. And put some kind of magic map inside. Giles: Activated by the brother's arrow. Willow: That was cool, with the Stonehenge and the grass and the stars. But um, well, we don't know if Apollo was Athena's brother. We don't know if they were gods or people or just stories. The Cylons know a lot about them, though. AF Cordelia: But the Cylons have one god. Oz: Right, but they're interested in the colonists' religion. I think they can use it to manipulate them or something. To the Cylons, God is one being, and he's perfect. His first children were imperfect, abandoned him for their superstitious polytheism, and became very unworthy, but they created a new generation of children who *are* perfect, or very close. (All the other AFs pause for a moment to absorb the fact that Oz has just narrated such a long passage.) Giles: And the children want to kill their parents. Oz: To eliminate imperfection, possibly. But first they have to perfect themselves. Buffy: By making themselves more human. Oz: Ironic, huh? They can't fulfill the commandment to multiply unless they experience one of the things that makes humans so imperfect: love. Giles: Well, this concept of one god certainly gives the Cylons a more unified purpose. The colonists seem quite... scattered and unsure. Cordelia: They *are* older. MB Anya: I bet it's that KILL ALL HUMANS robot thing that's giving the Cylons purpose. Oz: We'll see. Buffy: So... we're eventually going to talk about the fact that these children of humans have consciousness. Right? Cordelia: Yeah! Willow: And possibly souls? I think the main website Willow used was this Battlestar Wiki. Regarding the last part of their conversation, I want to refer them to one of the earlier episodes, but I think I'll write it out in a post of my own first.

Unlike last week's "Beachhead" experience, most of the AFs didn't tune in to Stargate SG-1this week, and Regular Xander didn't have much to report. In fact he was pretty bored by the whole episode.  Cordelia wasn't, entirely. 9x07 "Ex Deus Machina" AF Cordelia: This week was about Gold Head! R Xander: Teal'c.  I keep telling you. Cordelia: Fine.  It was about Talc.  Oh my god, he got to talk!  His voice gives me shivers.  But he was wearing these damn layered robes half the time. AF Willow, listening from atop the TV stand, was glad to hear a little bit about Sam's personal life and therefore didn't mind the artless exposition.  (She thinks of herself as a fellow scientist, so she digs Carter.)  Though she was curious about the "not-single" part. Willow: I don't understand why they don't say who she's with. R Xander:  Yeah, that's pretty dumb, but if you don't already know, I'm not telling you. My favorite thing, though, was Magic Box Anya's only comment: something to the effect that between Daniel's auctioneer-style exposition and his distracting hotness (I think he occasionally reminds her of Giles, which is odd but also not), she has no chance of understanding what's actually going on in the story.

Some of the Action Figures have begun their research assignments already: first was Miss Ceramic Kitty Fantastico, who, after the last conversation I reported, promptly leaped right off the edge of the TV stand, four and a half feet to her death. Well, that's what AF Willow must have thought, judging from her shriek. Really, MCKF hopped halfway down, where there's a stack of stuff next to the TV stand, and then the rest of the way to the (deep, soft) carpet on the second hop. Willow forgets that what they say about cats applies to the tiny ceramic ones as well, at least on carpet. MCKF scurried off to find the Fuzz and was apparently successful in her negotiations, because the AFs now have a very nice little rope ladder on which to descend and reascend the TV stand on research trips. Faith and Military Xander worked together on it, using two cords from the Fuzz's collection of string-type toys. Impressive, since I wasn't sure they could do something as nimble as tying knots. As soon as the ladder was finished, Fiesta Giles headed off on his trek to the study, where the books live. I'm not sure what he's been up to. The next thing I heard from the AFs was on Friday evening. I came back from my wine run to find the entire group of them hanging out on the far side of the couch. (They were trying to stay out of the way of the Fuzz; while most of them believe he's a *good* cat, not a one of them is foolish enough to think of him as actually *safe*. "He's not a tame cat," they remind one another.) The were waiting on me so they could watch Stargate: SG-1. Ha! How considerate. Willow knows how to use the TiVo remote by now, so they could have started without me. I thought SG-1 was Regular Xander's assignment, but I got the idea last night that the rest of them were either curious about the show from Xander's description or bored with life four feet off the floor. So they made this week's episode a group activity. It was rather festive, especially when I broke out the cheap wine (just for me--can you imagine what kind of alcohol tolerance a 3 ounce toy would have?) and cut up an apple into very small pieces. Unfortunately, I didn't have the foresight to set some viewing ground rules, and the buggers talked through the entire episode. None of them had actually seen the show before, so they were full of questions. It turns out (I should have realized this) even R Xander hasn't actually *seen* the show. He has, however, apparently listened very closely to every episode I've ever watched. What a geek. I gave them all a boost onto the couch, and as usual I sat on the floor with a cushion. This is how it went down while we watched Stargate: SG-1 9x06, "Beachhead": Regular Xander: Huh. I expected Jaffa to be so much more... built. Magic Box Anya: They're looking a little sickly, aren't they? They have those laser stick thingies though. Military Xander: Uh oh. Lot of good that did them. They should get some of the blue stone, ah, "stick thingies" instead. Can they stage a raid of some sort? R Xander: Staffs, I think, and no. Shut up, you'll see. AF Cordelia: What's wrong with that old guy's eyebrows--HELLO. Basketball. Oh my god, the Gold Head guy can dunk my basketball anytime. The rest of the action figures use the exposition about Nerus to ponder what exactly is the "basketball" in Cordelia's scenario, and what "dunking" would involve. From the look on her face, Willow thinks there should be a "hoop" in there somewhere, but she keeps quiet about it. M Xander: He's a TV person, sweetie. Cordelia: Whatever, he has to have an action figure at least. Willow, get on the internet tomorrow and find out. Willow: I'm glad to see you're dealing so well with the fact that we can be purchased. With *credit cards*. Cordelia: Pbbbblt. Get over it. LOOK at those arms. R Xander: Not bad. Looks like Mitchell hasn't joined the Black Tank Top club yet though. I'm sorry to have to return to the Action Figures' story right where I left off, which was a very sad scene in Rustydale. Lots of shell-shocked staring as a result of having found out their real origin. A sad scene indeed. Magic Box Anya had finished scrubbing her counter and Regular Xander was no longer even humming. (AF Faith, one of the few unaffected, had settled down with her head against Buffy's daisy-grown gravestone for a peaceful nap.) The silence was broken only by the occasional tap of Miss Ceramic Kitty Fantastico's paw on AF Willow's slippery, tear-streaked face, the almost imperceptible swish of tiny plastic weapons whipping through the air behind the wine bottle, and, every few minutes, a question from AF Cordelia: "Are we done moping yet?" After the tenth time or so, Xander, still lying on his back, picked up the purple peep head and chucked it at Cordy's. It looked like a bitter little argument was brewing, with Cordy dragging the still-dazed Military Xander into it for not sticking up for her, but just then there was a very authoritative throat-clearing sound from beside the wine bottle. AF Buffy had emerged from her therapeudic training session looking very determined. "Gang," she addressed them. She likes addressing them. None of them seem to mind. Except for Faith, those who were lying down sat up; the others turned to face her. "This is a bummer. I know. I thought... I don't know what I thought. It just sucks. But it doesn't change anything. Understand? Nothing is different! We're here, just like we were before. Okay?" Silence of a different quality, as they all worked on that thought. Some of those little guys are pretty smart for solid-headed plastic people, but a plastic brain is a plastic brain. "Everything is different." OF Oz. I should have known. He declined to elaborate, even when directly asked, "Different from what?" but I think about half of the AFs who cared about the issue at all agreed with him, based simply on intuition. If you found out you were something you had never imagined before, would it change everything or nothing? Eventually Magic Box Anya spoke up. "Why do I feel so bad?" It was a new thing for her, apparently. She cared why, exactly? "So we're copies of the TV people." Willow: Right. We knew that. MB Anya: And the TV people were made by humans. Buffy: Yes. Like us. Oz: Huh. MB Anya: What? Oz: Different creations of the same creators. Cordy: What? Stop thinking inside your head. Willow: (igoring Cordy) Oh, right! Like, we're equal with the TV people? Not just created in the image of something that was already a creation? Regular Xander was still feeling very mopey. "Creation of a creation of a creation, whatever, we're still the ones who are collectible," he said. Yeah, that has to hurt. They all knew it, but I think there was an unspoken concensus forming that there was no use speaking of it. Oz was going somewhere else, regardless. Oz: Who made them? MB Anya: Humans? Willow: Or the kittens! Or the rabbits? Military Xander: Or the jungle. Cordy: Or the beach. Faith: (not sleeping as she appeared) Don't forget leather. Regular Xander: Maybe it has to do with Origin. Willow, who paid attention to Xander's hobbies, picked up on the obscure reference. Willow: How much Stargate are you watching these days? R Xander: No, really, there's these dudes, and they say— Buffy: Hold on, what are we talking about here? Willow: Xander's sci fi shows teach him about religion. Oz: Religion. Huh. Cordy: Would you stop that? Somehow that all led to a discussion about gods and worship; they had heard of the terms, though even Oz had only a vague idea what was involved. Was worship something that was necessary? Should they worship the human who sculpted them? The human who made the creations in whose image they were sculpted? Humans in general? Something above humans? Was there something above humans? The Great Cat? Buffy and Cordelia felt that with all the new ideas out there, they shouldn't get into anything hastily, so they decided to drop the idea for awhile. Regular Xander kept bringing up robots for some reason. Fiesta Giles, still sitting with his back to the wine bottle, had been very quiet through everything, and both Willow and Buffy must have taken note, because I noticed they both looked relieved when he finally spoke. "Xander has a point, little as he knows it. There's also consciousness to be considered, you know." Giles reached up to his face as if searching for glasses, but found nothing for his hands to do. "Sentience, consciousness, the soul..." He seemed to lose his thought again. "So this is bigger than us," Buffy said, displaying a surprising understading of the concepts Giles had named. "I mean, yes! This is what I was saying! Nothing has changed. We're still us, right where we were." Oz looked almost like he wanted to argue that that Giles's comment supported his original point more than Buffy's, but he didn't bother. For her part, Cordy, was just relieved they seemed to be getting somewhere. "Good. Bigger. Okay, what do we do?" she said, standing up and looking at them all with hands on her plastic hips. Giles gazed at her. "Well, I should think the answer was obvious. We research." Excellent. I'm both encouraged and made uneasy by this development. On one hand, constructive action, yay! On the other hand, focused research hasn't done them any favors so far. Think of what they might get into! And wait til you hear the research assignments they've handed out. Hoo boy.

Previously in Rustydale, the action figures decided to figure out where they came from. I was gone over the weekend, and I returned to my apartment Sunday night to discover a minor disaster area.  The first thing I noticed was my laptop: opened, turned on, still dialed up to the internet, and ominously abandoned.  I turned to the study and found the bookshelves looking somewhat ransacked—books turned down on their spines, Buffy swag knocked on the floor, and my musical carousel horse turned to face the wall.  The floor and armchair, which aren't that tidy to begin with these days, were littered with the plastic sacks and collapsed cardboard boxes I store behind the chair for when I want to mail a package.  Even more ominously, the window was open a crack and the screen looked a little pushed-out. Back in the main room, I noticed seven large cards splayed out on the floor at the foot of the television stand: the cardboard backings of the packages most of my action figures came in.  They were all turned back-side up, each with the name, photo and description of the character and the little insets showing the faces of the action figure series the character was part of.  A couple of the cards seemed to have little tears around the edges that I don't remember making myself. Obviously my cat didn't do all this. The pieces were starting to fall together, so I checked the computer again.  My Firefox browser was still up on the task bar.  AF Willow—it had to be her—had left a clear trail of tabs.  Google search for "buffy+willow+plastic," then an Entertainment Earth page, which must have been the first horrible shock, then another Entertainment Earth page, a Google search for "Diamond Select Toys," and finally this. I have to admit, there was a moment where I involuntarily geeked out.  They're selling a "Fear Itself" Anya with a removeable Bunny suit now? How cool is that?  But I got back to the rather important matter at hand.  And can I tell you how much I didn't want to check on my action figures at this point?  But there was no avoiding it. On top of the TV stand, as I feared, it was pretty sad sight.  Regular Xander was lying on his back staring at the ceiling and clearly wouldn't let anyone talk to him.  I think I heard him humming some country song.  Military Xander was furiously cleaning his machine gun, which of course is not complicated when the weapon is a solid piece of plastic, but I don't think he knew the difference.  Oz and Willow were sitting back to back, each staring into space, tiny puddles collected in the plastic creases of Willow's clothes. Miss Ceramic Kitty Fantastico was standing in her lap, patting gently at her wet face. *Tap, tap* went the ceramic paw against the plastic face. Magic Box Anya, with no Xander to talk to, was acting much like Military Xander and furiously cleaning her already-clean counter and cash register.  Giles was sitting with his back to the blue wine bottle looking very deep in thought, occasionally muttering something to himself that sounded like "proof of purchase, made in China," and I peeked behind the bottle to discover Buffy in the middle of a very complicated-looking training routine involving about six weapons.  Only Faith and Cordelia seemed unchanged.  Faith was casually whittling stakes out of some twigs she found in the flower arrangement—she may have actually been whistling—and Cordelia appeared to be trying to catch her reflection in the patio window.  Oh, and don't ask me how I could tell, it's only a general impression, but Bunny Anya just looked hungry. So. My action figures have found out they are mass-produced toys.  Not just fashioned by another being, which probably would have been okay, but manufactured in quantity. I suppose it's like I might feel if I found out I was one of hundreds of the same clone.  Poor little buggers.  I don't suppose it would do any good right now telling them they're special to me.  Guess I'll just have to wait and see how this shakes out.

Previously in Rustydale, the action figures smoked out and started to get existential. AF Willow wouldn't let it go. She was very worried, or maybe paranoid. Giles's idea made some kind of sense, though they weren't sure why. Weed-muddled brains, and all that. Oz: As what? Buffy: What what? Oz: As what were we fashioned? By whom? For what purpose? Are you sure we aren't just later generations of chemical compounds that formed through natural processes? Silence reined for a minute as their minds were blown like explosions in space. Giles: No, she's quite right, for all we know someone met us while we were in stasis and then created the people on TV out of humans. Cordelia: This is too confusing. The Xanders and Faith also tried to process this through their haze. (Eavesdropping, I was across the room and unaffected by the flower smoke, but I still agreed with Cordelia.) Buffy straightened up more than she was, looking determined. Buffy: Okay, that doesn't answer Oz's questions, but we need to know this. I don't know why, but it's important.  If you each think about it for a minute, you'll realize you think so too.  We need to know where we're from. So we can know where we're supposed to be going. We've been just sitting around on this TV stand for too long with no purpose. MB Anya:  What matters is that we're here now. I don't know about you, but I can decide for myself where I'm going. Hopefully to great business success. Oz: This may not end well. Buffy: I don't care. We're doing it. Gang? Despite Magic Box Anya's indifference and Oz's misgivings, the action figures decided to take up the quest. That was all several days ago. Over the weekend, they found some answers. The poor things.

TinyGachnar, after weeks of being casually toyed with by AF Faith, escaped by jumping off the TV tower, landing unharmed on the carpet below, hopping with dificulty through the thick pile to the screen door where he snuck out one of the times I was going in and out with the watering can. That's what AF Willow figured out in her crime scene investigation, anyway. (AF Giles argued no crime had been committed, but Willow was so eager to use the forensic knowledge she's been compiling—apparently they all like to watch C.S.I. while I'm out—that he dropped it.) Her findings included the note that Gachnar's one-piece, jointless composition made it easier for him to avoid injury but harder to move about in deep carpet. Magic Box!Anya, who arrived in December and has been acting rather chummy with the Fuzz as she negotiates to get him to bring her inventory for her store, accused the Fuzz of being a horrible guard cat. The Fuzz replied with a disinterested stare that said it's no furr off his paws if a tiny plastic demon decides to take a stroll among the obstacles of fallen birdseed. I think the AFs had been getting fond of Gachnar, in the way you might come to appreciate a vicious chihuahua: it keeps things interesting, and it's SO CUTE! if you avoid the teeth. None of them had been outside, though, and most seemed a bit wary. They've seen the birds out there. A blackbird or red-bellied woodpecker could carry one of them away easily, and that's saying nothing of the squirrels and the monstrous racoon that's in the habit of visiting each night around 9 p.m. It wasn't long before Military Xander, over AF Cordy's protests about squirrel scratches on his face-paint, volunteered to go on the hunt. He requested that Miss Ceramic Kitty Fantastico and Bunny, the Gift With Purchase who hitched a ride with Magic Box Anya, accompany him. Supposedly he has been training them in search, attack, and subduing the enemey, and he wanted them to get some real world experience. I'm not sure how they all got down; Bunny* (being of the same one-piece plastic construction as Gachnar) could have jumped. But Willow, still with the missing limb trauma I guess, started freaking out thinking about Miss Kitty and Military Xander jumping all that way. I think they ended up improvising a rope out of the fibers of salvaged basket reeds. (AF Buffy's idea; AF Oz's technique.) M Xander was about to use a plastic sword to widen the tear in the screen the Fuzz had made while going after the racoon, but I stopped him, replaced the duct tape, and let them out the door. The rest unfolded thusly:
  1. Bunny hides in the violets.
  2. Where's Bunny? Seriously, does she think Gachnar's going to walk past her patch of the pot? Good hiding, though.
  3. Military Xander catches a glimpse of black plastic leather above, in the pole bean jungle pot. He immdiately calls out, "Fear Demon," then drops to his articulated knees and begins to sob, overcome with the emotion of finding a creature that has been sought for so long and no one thought would be seen again. (Whatever, sissy.)
  4. Miss Kitty, climbing over the lip of the bean pot right in front of the quarry, distracts it while Military Xander approaches silently from behind, plastic boots sinking in the soft wet potting soil.
  5. Gachnar, knowing all is lost (having failed miserably at inducing fear in the bird and squirrel populations), rushes past Miss Kitty and flings himself to the balcony boards below, evoking a tiny involuntary scream from inside, where AF Willow has been watching anxiously at the window. A louder scream rings out when Miss Kitty follows him—but into the soft soil of the next-smaller pot, and again into a still smaller one. Bunny catches it all from her fear demon blind and hops into the action herself.
  6. Kitten and rabbit do Military Xander proud by stopping Tiny Gachnar before he has a chance to take three hops. MCKF crouches behind his legs, and Bunny leaps up, soundly thumping his chest with her hind feet. He topples, and they've got him.
  7. Military Xander moves to the edge to view the action and (feeling a little outdone) offer pointers from above.
Mission accomplished! * Bunny doesn't know she's a mild-mannered domestic creature. When she and Anya were being packaged together, before the box was sealed and they went into stasis, Anya was so afraid of her that she concluded she was some kind of monster designed to attack and kill with fangs and claws, possibly guarding a cave in England.

This year, the AFs are assembled on top of a new, much sturdier piece of furniture called a TV Stand. It didn't shake when the VC came calling, and there's plenty of room to spread out. Also, with them far above the TV, they can't actually *see* what's going on, on the tube. That has been quite fortunate a couple of times during Angel. But can't they *hear*, you say? Right. And Bunny Anya is especially alert for some reason. (She loves to listen to the TV, when she's not chattering at Fiesta Giles about schemes for renting out to other AFs as a hired thug, or becoming a roaming band of high-priced catburglars, famous for their ability to get in through holes and cracks that would confound even a monkey.) So I had to do something about Angel. I ended up enlisting AFWillow's help. She agreed, on the condition she could tell Oz what was going on. Since Oz isn't exactly a big conversationalist, it was okay with me. So now, every Wednesday night at 8, Willow casts a deafness spell with a pinch of sleep. They can't hear the episode, and most of them are nodding off anyway, so they don't notice their deafness. The others haven't caught on to the fact that Oz starts plumping up his chain-bedecked gravestone every Wednesday at 7:55. There was one hitch, a pretty big one. One week back in early February, Willow was a bit late, and she had just finished discreetly performing the spell for all the others as the teaser was starting on the TV. She was sitting down with Oz's head in her lap (as much of a lap as she can form when her legs don't quite go straight), getting ready to apply a dab of potion to her own forehead, when she heard the voice of Real Cordelia "downstairs." I of course wasn't at all aware of the doings on *top* of the TV. So I didn't notice when Willow put down her little bottle and sat, for the next hour, listening intently. Around 9:30, when I stopped crying for a little while, I heard wee sniffling noises coming from the Stand. At that moment, Action Figure Cordelia shook herself awake and looked over at Willow. "What's *your* problem?" she said in typical style. Willow burst into nearly hysterical tears, waking Oz, who of course then held her. The others gathered around, and Giles stooped (with difficulty under the weight of his poncho, which RustyNiece had decreed he wear) and gently asked her what was wrong. She hiccupped out some story about renewed grief over her missing arm. "I thought she was finished with that problem," Anya said firmly, to no one in particular. And in a bright, helpful tone, "Willow, you finished that, remember?" At that point I stepped in. I rarely do, but I felt like this situation merited a private sit-down. Poor AFWillow. For someone without internal organs, she is terribly tenderhearted. So far, AFWillow and I have been able to keep the news from the rest of the crew. It took a few days of puzzled pampering from Oz and some cryptic talks with Giles about the nature of death and reality, but she's dealing pretty well now.

Big action figure news: the unexpected arrival of The Other[Willow]s. For now, though, the news is only big to me, because it's going to be awhile before these variously frightening plastic ladies interact with the group, if it happens at all. The group is doing well. They've taken the tumbly ride to Catventureland a few times, packed into their Funbag, where who knows what will touch whose whatever for how long. After emerging, they have had RustyNiece adventures, of which, despite the usual spells, a couple of them are starting remember bits and pieces. Hopefully they won't put anything together and wonder why Oz was forced to marry Cordelia or why Xander and Buffy were briefly dating. The biggest thing that has happened was the introduction of AF Faith and Red Pants Buffy. It was almost a year ago, I believe, just in time for the Buffy finale. It seemed the gang needed even more distraction, though. So I freed Faith from stasis and let her climb from my hand onto the bookshelf where the others were, tensely awaiting the something big they could feel was coming (but that I didn't want them to witness). Alpha female as she is, AF Faith sensed a rival and stalked straight up to Red Pants Buffy before Military Xander had a chance to scramble for his gun or get out so much as a "State your business." The women stood sizing each other up. AF Faith: So, you're the big stuff around here? You aren't very big, sister. AF Buffy: It's Buffy. And I don't have to be, not that it's any of your business. Who are you? What are you doing here, anyway? AF Faith: Faith, been asleep, now I'm not. You got a problem with that? AF BuffyNo. I do have a problem with your combat boots, but hey, looking good isn't for everybody. AF Faith: Yeah? Well, I'm not the one with legs made of crappy-ass solid red plastic. Your clothes aren't even painted on! AF Cordy: She *does* look really hot, Buffy. None of the action figures had known for sure that their eyebrows could move, but at that comment Xander's furrowed stiffly. Buffy glared at Cordelia before continuing. AF Buffy: At least I don't have nasty black nail polish. And my boots look *good*. AF Faith: They'd look better if you had any joints below your knees. I bet you fall over *real* easy, B. AF Faith had of course invoked the action figure's greatest indignity, but she finally crossed the line by reaching up and giving AF Buffy a small, experimental shove. Then they were at it. Buffy did actually start to fall, but she grabbed Faith's hair and pulled her down as well. Faith grunted something about kicking Buffy's genuine plastic ass. A catfight between tiny molded plastic women with less than 20 joints apiece, rolling around a bookshelf while other plastic people try to avoid getting toppled, is really something to see. For awhile it looked like Faith's flexible ankles were going to be a match for Buffy's stylish yet slightly more impractical boots. Cordelia and Xander, both excellent fighters themselves, tried to join in, but Buffy barked at them to stay out of it. It was only when Bunny Anya, who had been watching from a distance with considerable amusement (one could only guess she wished she had some popcorn), decided to send a real cat into the fray, that things started to cool down. Miss Ceramic Kitty Fantastico leaped in yowling her hardest, and if she had no actual ceramic claws to unsheath, she at least gave the impression she did. Buffy and Faith were still. They had paused while Buffy was on top, with Faith's curled plastic fist gripping her jaw, about to twist her neck, perhaps employ the popular AF "pop your enemy's head off" move. They stayed that way, emitting tiny panting noises (though their chests are unable to heave), looking at each other intensely. The others were dead silent.
